[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m> # Agentic Marker System Design[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI have a project which I want to accomplish ASAP. This task is helping me create a system for draft marking for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignments submitted by students in a class I teach using LLMs invkoed fromCLI. The students submit Jupyter notebook [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles as their submissions. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThere are two kinds of assignments:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 1. Fill-in-the-blank style assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThese Jupyter notebook files are filled copies of a fill-in-the-blank kind of notebook, where students start with a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstarter notebook, and they have to implement what is asked. Some assignments have rubrics, which are included in the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook, and some don't. Also, the starter notebooks are structured: activities that have to be done by students are [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecified by "[A<i>]" in which i is the activity number. The sections students have to fill are enclosed between text [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcells "*Start student input* â†“" and "*End student input â†‘*". There may be multiple cells between those, and both code [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand text kinds. They are free to add more cells if they like; however, they are asked not to change anything outside [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose limits. Also, some cells come with some pieces of code already filled in. I've broken down the task into [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple steps:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the unfilled version of the notebook. The [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent identifies the activities that have to be done, how many there are, and their order, and writes a concise but [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdetailed account of what needs to be done for each activity in a separate markdown file. The agent also writes a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mconcise summary of what students were supposed to have accomplished before, especially as it pertains to the activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mat hand. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into those per-activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarkdown files. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by another "marker" agent, so the markdown files [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshould be written with that in mind. Finally, this agent writes an overall markdown file which includes the rubric, if[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m already included, or creates a sensible rubric if there is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mabout student proficiency levels and is not inferable from the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwho is the instructor of the course, to provide guidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhether the agent can assume the students have a specific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the proficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThis questioning, if necessary, is done after the agent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance document in markdown for itself (also, at the beginning, the instructor may also optionally provide and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment description package which explain the goals of the assignment, which can also be used, if provided). Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthen creates those per activity marking design documents. Finally, they create that final overall document, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mincludes the rubric, given or created, unchanged or updated, extended by the detailed marking criteria and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexpectations it created per activity.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, and m activities to be done, m sets of n "marker" agents are called, one[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m set per activity. Each agent is provided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthat activity. These agents are supposed to mark the solutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0midentify all the mistakes the students made, as well as their positive points, and record the result of their marking [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0min a markdown document named after the activity number, as well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched, one per activity, which looks at all the markings done in those markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles created by the marker agents, for all students on that activity and based on that, unifies them into a table of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmistakes and positives and identify the severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgiven for positives and write them to another markdown file for that activity the agent was handling.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then aggregated in one document for all activities and presented to the instructor in a table, which has [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0malongside it a distribution of marks students will get if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarking number and observe the results on the distribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mExcel file or any form that makes the best sense for this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they got[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m for each activity, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 2. Free-form assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThe workflow here is similar to the above, but instead of starting from a fill-in-the-blank notebook, students start [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfrom an empty notebook and have to do everything from scratch. The marking pattern designer agent has to figure out [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat the activities are based on the assignment description provided by the instructor in a separate markdown file, as[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m well as any rubric provided. Specifically, the steps are:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the assignment description package (set of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles). The agent identifies the activities that have to be done and writes a concise but detailed account of what [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mneeds to be done. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into a markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by the "marker" agent, so the markdown files should be written [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwith that in mind. This file should also includes the rubric, if already included, or create a sensible rubric if [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthere is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge about student proficiency levels and is not inferable [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfrom the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, who is the instructor of the course, to provide [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about whether the agent can assume the students have a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mproficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. This questioning, if necessary, is done after the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal guidance document in markdown for itself. Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcreates a final overall document.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, n "marker" agents are called, one set per student. Each agent is [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprovided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design. These agents are supposed to mark the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0msolutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather identify all the mistakes the students made, as well as [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mtheir positive points, and record the result of their marking in a markdown document named after the activity number, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mas well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched which looks at all the markings done in those markdown files created by the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarker agents, for all students, and based on that, unifies them into a table of mistakes and positives and identify [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthe severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points given for positives and write them to [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0manother markdown file.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then presented to the instructor in a table, which has alongside it a distribution of marks students will [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mget if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the marking number and observe the results on the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdistribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or Excel file or any form that makes the best sense [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgot, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## Implementation details[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI am trying to accomplish this with CLI LLM tools, specifically Claude Code, Codex and Gemini (search the web for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minformation and documentation if you don't know how these work). Not all these tools have the same usage details, so [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfirst we have to write a unified caller, which is a shell file that takes as input a prompt, a run mode which is [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0meither interactive (default) or headless, an optional provider, i.e., "claude", "gemini", "codex" or an optional model[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m "claude-sonnet-4", "gemini-3-pro-preview", "gpt-5.1", ..., which the utilities and agents can use to call other [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magents. Calls to "marking pattern designer" and to "aggregator" agents are done in interactive sessions (for Claude [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0myou can supply the initial prompt via stdin if there isn't a way to start an interactive session but one where you [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprovide the initial prompt via CLI, or a better way if you know one) and the conversation transcript is saved to a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfile via:[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```sh[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  script <appropriate_session_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  <call>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  # ...interact...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  exit. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mor a better way if you know one. These agents will indicate to the user when they can exit for the rest of the marking[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m process to continue when their part is done. Calls to "marker", "normalizer" and "unifier" agents are done using [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mheadless or exec mode and the output of every call is captured in an approprite file, so we keep track of the entire [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mevent. If not specified per agent type, all agents will use the default provider and model specified in a project [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0moverview file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mYou can assume the assignments are located within a subdirectory in the project directory called assignments, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhas a strcutrue like this:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```files[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”œâ”€â”€ assignments[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <assignment_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <base_file>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <other_file_1>.ipynb\[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ overview.md[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   |   â””â”€â”€ submissions[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ <section_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_2[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_k[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ <submission_name>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mNote that submission notebook files may be in a nested subdirectory structure within each section. Also, that they may[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m contain spaces in their names, so take that into consideration when handling them.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mPut all your artefacts under a `assignments/<assignment_name>/processed` subdirectory, in appropriate subdirectories [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand with appropriate names. The file `overview.md` is where we will keep the optional project overview with links ot [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mother files in the desscription package if there are more, including default provider and model and the name of the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mbase file in the strcutrued case, as well as any other relevant information. You can set up a specific strcuture for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to specify the including default provider and model and the name of the base file, but it does not neccesarily [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhave to be the first lines in the file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, I would like the instructor to be informed of the marking progress. a way to have a progress indicator, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshows we are at what question and which of the students have been already marked alongside a progress percentage, all [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprinted like a console log, that would be a nice extra. We progress activity by activity and inside that student by [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstudent in the structured case and student by student in the free-form case. We inform what is being done and when it [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mis completed and we also display <current_activity_index>/<total_activities_number> and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m<current_student_index>/<total_students_number> as well as in percentages.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, to minimize context, in the structured assignment case, we can break the submission of each student down to [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexactly what they did for each activity and only feed that to the marker agents via writing an activity extractor [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfunction we develop. In the structured case, all students are allowed to change is sandwiched between text cells [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m"Start student input â†“" and "End student input â†‘". Under a specific [A<i>] indicating the assignment. There may be [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple of these delimited input places per activity, all of which are distinct and belong to that activity until the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m next activity, i.e., [A<i+1>] in a text cell further down. Also, there may be more than one cell in each delimited [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minput places and it can be any combo of text and code cells. So, we can extract all these cells sandwiched between [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose delimited cells and all under a specific activity, all for that activity. You can find an example of a base [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook of the structured kind in the `dev/examples/structured_assignment_example.ipynb` file, if that helps you.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, be mindful of the prompts you create for the agents if there is a maximum token size for them.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAcknowledge you understand what I am trying to do, present you with suggestions for the instructor mark adjustment [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument kind (with the editable tables and live distribution graph) as well as the final output aggregated marks [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument, then list all the artefacts and documents that are produced in this process, and lastly suggest a plan on [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to implement this project using Claude Code Web. Also, comment on what you think about this structure I devised [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this project. Let me approve and verify this plan, and then let's start building it ASAP. [39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m> # Agentic Marker System Design[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI have a project which I want to accomplish ASAP. This task is helping me create a system for draft marking for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignments submitted by students in a class I teach using LLMs invkoed fromCLI. The students submit Jupyter notebook [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles as their submissions. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThere are two kinds of assignments:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 1. Fill-in-the-blank style assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThese Jupyter notebook files are filled copies of a fill-in-the-blank kind of notebook, where students start with a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstarter notebook, and they have to implement what is asked. Some assignments have rubrics, which are included in the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook, and some don't. Also, the starter notebooks are structured: activities that have to be done by students are [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecified by "[A<i>]" in which i is the activity number. The sections students have to fill are enclosed between text [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcells "*Start student input* â†“" and "*End student input â†‘*". There may be multiple cells between those, and both code [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand text kinds. They are free to add more cells if they like; however, they are asked not to change anything outside [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose limits. Also, some cells come with some pieces of code already filled in. I've broken down the task into [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple steps:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the unfilled version of the notebook. The [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent identifies the activities that have to be done, how many there are, and their order, and writes a concise but [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdetailed account of what needs to be done for each activity in a separate markdown file. The agent also writes a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mconcise summary of what students were supposed to have accomplished before, especially as it pertains to the activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mat hand. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into those per-activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarkdown files. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by another "marker" agent, so the markdown files [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshould be written with that in mind. Finally, this agent writes an overall markdown file which includes the rubric, if[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m already included, or creates a sensible rubric if there is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mabout student proficiency levels and is not inferable from the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwho is the instructor of the course, to provide guidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhether the agent can assume the students have a specific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the proficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThis questioning, if necessary, is done after the agent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance document in markdown for itself (also, at the beginning, the instructor may also optionally provide and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment description package which explain the goals of the assignment, which can also be used, if provided). Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthen creates those per activity marking design documents. Finally, they create that final overall document, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mincludes the rubric, given or created, unchanged or updated, extended by the detailed marking criteria and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexpectations it created per activity.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, and m activities to be done, m sets of n "marker" agents are called, one[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m set per activity. Each agent is provided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthat activity. These agents are supposed to mark the solutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0midentify all the mistakes the students made, as well as their positive points, and record the result of their marking [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0min a markdown document named after the activity number, as well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched, one per activity, which looks at all the markings done in those markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles created by the marker agents, for all students on that activity and based on that, unifies them into a table of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmistakes and positives and identify the severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgiven for positives and write them to another markdown file for that activity the agent was handling.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then aggregated in one document for all activities and presented to the instructor in a table, which has [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0malongside it a distribution of marks students will get if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarking number and observe the results on the distribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mExcel file or any form that makes the best sense for this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they got[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m for each activity, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mtheir positive points, and record the result of their marking in a markdown document named after the activity number, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mas well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched which looks at all the markings done in those markdown files created by the [39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthe severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdistribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or Excel file or any form that makes the best sense [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## Implementation details[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI am trying to accomplish this with CLI LLM tools, specifically Claude Code, Codex and Gemini (search the web for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minformation and documentation if you don't know how these work). Not all these tools have the same usage details, so [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfirst we have to write a unified caller, which is a shell file that takes as input a prompt, a run mode which is [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0meither interactive (default) or headless, an optional provider, i.e., "claude", "gemini", "codex" or an optional model[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m "claude-sonnet-4", "gemini-3-pro-preview", "gpt-5.1", ..., which the utilities and agents can use to call other [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magents. Calls to "marking pattern designer" and to "aggregator" agents are done in interactive sessions (for Claude [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0myou can supply the initial prompt via stdin if there isn't a way to start an interactive session but one where you [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprovide the initial prompt via CLI, or a better way if you know one) and the conversation transcript is saved to a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfile via:[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```sh[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  script <appropriate_session_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  <call>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  # ...interact...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  exit. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mor a better way if you know one. These agents will indicate to the user when they can exit for the rest of the marking[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m process to continue when their part is done. Calls to "marker", "normalizer" and "unifier" agents are done using [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mheadless or exec mode and the output of every call is captured in an approprite file, so we keep track of the entire [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mevent. If not specified per agent type, all agents will use the default provider and model specified in a project [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0moverview file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mYou can assume the assignments are located within a subdirectory in the project directory called assignments, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhas a strcutrue like this:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```files[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”œâ”€â”€ assignments[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <assignment_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <base_file>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <other_file_1>.ipynb\[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ overview.md[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   |   â””â”€â”€ submissions[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ <section_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_2[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_k[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ <submission_name>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mNote that submission notebook files may be in a nested subdirectory structure within each section. Also, that they may[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m contain spaces in their names, so take that into consideration when handling them.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mPut all your artefacts under a `assignments/<assignment_name>/processed` subdirectory, in appropriate subdirectories [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand with appropriate names. The file `overview.md` is where we will keep the optional project overview with links ot [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mother files in the desscription package if there are more, including default provider and model and the name of the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mbase file in the strcutrued case, as well as any other relevant information. You can set up a specific strcuture for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to specify the including default provider and model and the name of the base file, but it does not neccesarily [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhave to be the first lines in the file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, I would like the instructor to be informed of the marking progress. a way to have a progress indicator, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshows we are at what question and which of the students have been already marked alongside a progress percentage, all [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprinted like a console log, that would be a nice extra. We progress activity by activity and inside that student by [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstudent in the structured case and student by student in the free-form case. We inform what is being done and when it [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mis completed and we also display <current_activity_index>/<total_activities_number> and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m<current_student_index>/<total_students_number> as well as in percentages.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, to minimize context, in the structured assignment case, we can break the submission of each student down to [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexactly what they did for each activity and only feed that to the marker agents via writing an activity extractor [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfunction we develop. In the structured case, all students are allowed to change is sandwiched between text cells [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m"Start student input â†“" and "End student input â†‘". Under a specific [A<i>] indicating the assignment. There may be [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple of these delimited input places per activity, all of which are distinct and belong to that activity until the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m next activity, i.e., [A<i+1>] in a text cell further down. Also, there may be more than one cell in each delimited [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minput places and it can be any combo of text and code cells. So, we can extract all these cells sandwiched between [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose delimited cells and all under a specific activity, all for that activity. You can find an example of a base [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook of the structured kind in the `dev/examples/structured_assignment_example.ipynb` file, if that helps you.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, be mindful of the prompts you create for the agents if there is a maximum token size for them.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAcknowledge you understand what I am trying to do, present you with suggestions for the instructor mark adjustment [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument kind (with the editable tables and live distribution graph) as well as the final output aggregated marks [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument, then list all the artefacts and documents that are produced in this process, and lastly suggest a plan on [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to implement this project using Claude Code Web. Also, comment on what you think about this structure I devised [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this project. Let me approve and verify this plan, and then let's start building it ASAP. [39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m> # Agentic Marker System Design[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI have a project which I want to accomplish ASAP. This task is helping me create a system for draft marking for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignments submitted by students in a class I teach using LLMs invkoed fromCLI. The students submit Jupyter notebook [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles as their submissions. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThere are two kinds of assignments:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 1. Fill-in-the-blank style assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThese Jupyter notebook files are filled copies of a fill-in-the-blank kind of notebook, where students start with a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstarter notebook, and they have to implement what is asked. Some assignments have rubrics, which are included in the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook, and some don't. Also, the starter notebooks are structured: activities that have to be done by students are [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecified by "[A<i>]" in which i is the activity number. The sections students have to fill are enclosed between text [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcells "*Start student input* â†“" and "*End student input â†‘*". There may be multiple cells between those, and both code [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand text kinds. They are free to add more cells if they like; however, they are asked not to change anything outside [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose limits. Also, some cells come with some pieces of code already filled in. I've broken down the task into [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple steps:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the unfilled version of the notebook. The [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent identifies the activities that have to be done, how many there are, and their order, and writes a concise but [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdetailed account of what needs to be done for each activity in a separate markdown file. The agent also writes a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mconcise summary of what students were supposed to have accomplished before, especially as it pertains to the activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mat hand. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into those per-activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarkdown files. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by another "marker" agent, so the markdown files [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshould be written with that in mind. Finally, this agent writes an overall markdown file which includes the rubric, if[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m already included, or creates a sensible rubric if there is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mabout student proficiency levels and is not inferable from the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwho is the instructor of the course, to provide guidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhether the agent can assume the students have a specific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the proficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThis questioning, if necessary, is done after the agent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance document in markdown for itself (also, at the beginning, the instructor may also optionally provide and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment description package which explain the goals of the assignment, which can also be used, if provided). Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthen creates those per activity marking design documents. Finally, they create that final overall document, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mincludes the rubric, given or created, unchanged or updated, extended by the detailed marking criteria and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexpectations it created per activity.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, and m activities to be done, m sets of n "marker" agents are called, one[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m set per activity. Each agent is provided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthat activity. These agents are supposed to mark the solutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0midentify all the mistakes the students made, as well as their positive points, and record the result of their marking [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0min a markdown document named after the activity number, as well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched, one per activity, which looks at all the markings done in those markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles created by the marker agents, for all students on that activity and based on that, unifies them into a table of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmistakes and positives and identify the severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgiven for positives and write them to another markdown file for that activity the agent was handling.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then aggregated in one document for all activities and presented to the instructor in a table, which has [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0malongside it a distribution of marks students will get if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarking number and observe the results on the distribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mExcel file or any form that makes the best sense for this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they got[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m for each activity, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 2. Free-form assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThe workflow here is similar to the above, but instead of starting from a fill-in-the-blank notebook, students start [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfrom an empty notebook and have to do everything from scratch. The marking pattern designer agent has to figure out [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat the activities are based on the assignment description provided by the instructor in a separate markdown file, as[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m well as any rubric provided. Specifically, the steps are:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the assignment description package (set of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles). The agent identifies the activities that have to be done and writes a concise but detailed account of what [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mneeds to be done. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into a markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by the "marker" agent, so the markdown files should be written [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwith that in mind. This file should also includes the rubric, if already included, or create a sensible rubric if [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthere is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge about student proficiency levels and is not inferable [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfrom the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, who is the instructor of the course, to provide [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about whether the agent can assume the students have a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mproficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. This questioning, if necessary, is done after the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal guidance document in markdown for itself. Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcreates a final overall document.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, n "marker" agents are called, one set per student. Each agent is [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprovided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design. These agents are supposed to mark the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0msolutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather identify all the mistakes the students made, as well as [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mtheir positive points, and record the result of their marking in a markdown document named after the activity number, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mas well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched which looks at all the markings done in those markdown files created by the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarker agents, for all students, and based on that, unifies them into a table of mistakes and positives and identify [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthe severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points given for positives and write them to [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0manother markdown file.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then presented to the instructor in a table, which has alongside it a distribution of marks students will [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mget if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the marking number and observe the results on the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdistribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or Excel file or any form that makes the best sense [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgot, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## Implementation details[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI am trying to accomplish this with CLI LLM tools, specifically Claude Code, Codex and Gemini (search the web for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minformation and documentation if you don't know how these work). Not all these tools have the same usage details, so [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfirst we have to write a unified caller, which is a shell file that takes as input a prompt, a run mode which is [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0meither interactive (default) or headless, an optional provider, i.e., "claude", "gemini", "codex" or an optional model[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m "claude-sonnet-4", "gemini-3-pro-preview", "gpt-5.1", ..., which the utilities and agents can use to call other [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magents. Calls to "marking pattern designer" and to "aggregator" agents are done in interactive sessions (for Claude [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0myou can supply the initial prompt via stdin if there isn't a way to start an interactive session but one where you [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprovide the initial prompt via CLI, or a better way if you know one) and the conversation transcript is saved to a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfile via:[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```sh[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  script <appropriate_session_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  <call>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  # ...interact...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  exit. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  ```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m  [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mor a better way if you know one. These agents will indicate to the user when they can exit for the rest of the marking[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m process to continue when their part is done. Calls to "marker", "normalizer" and "unifier" agents are done using [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mheadless or exec mode and the output of every call is captured in an approprite file, so we keep track of the entire [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mevent. If not specified per agent type, all agents will use the default provider and model specified in a project [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0moverview file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mYou can assume the assignments are located within a subdirectory in the project directory called assignments, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhas a strcutrue like this:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```files[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”œâ”€â”€ assignments[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <assignment_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <base_file>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ <other_file_1>.ipynb\[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ overview.md[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mâ”‚   |   â””â”€â”€ submissions[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ <section_name>[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_2[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â”œâ”€â”€ subdir_k[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ <submission_name>.ipynb[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       |        â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â”‚        â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m|   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ ...[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m```[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mNote that submission notebook files may be in a nested subdirectory structure within each section. Also, that they may[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m contain spaces in their names, so take that into consideration when handling them.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mPut all your artefacts under a `assignments/<assignment_name>/processed` subdirectory, in appropriate subdirectories [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand with appropriate names. The file `overview.md` is where we will keep the optional project overview with links ot [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mother files in the desscription package if there are more, including default provider and model and the name of the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mbase file in the strcutrued case, as well as any other relevant information. You can set up a specific strcuture for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to specify the including default provider and model and the name of the base file, but it does not neccesarily [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhave to be the first lines in the file.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, I would like the instructor to be informed of the marking progress. a way to have a progress indicator, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshows we are at what question and which of the students have been already marked alongside a progress percentage, all [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mprinted like a console log, that would be a nice extra. We progress activity by activity and inside that student by [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstudent in the structured case and student by student in the free-form case. We inform what is being done and when it [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mis completed and we also display <current_activity_index>/<total_activities_number> and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m<current_student_index>/<total_students_number> as well as in percentages.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, to minimize context, in the structured assignment case, we can break the submission of each student down to [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexactly what they did for each activity and only feed that to the marker agents via writing an activity extractor [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfunction we develop. In the structured case, all students are allowed to change is sandwiched between text cells [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m"Start student input â†“" and "End student input â†‘". Under a specific [A<i>] indicating the assignment. There may be [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple of these delimited input places per activity, all of which are distinct and belong to that activity until the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m next activity, i.e., [A<i+1>] in a text cell further down. Also, there may be more than one cell in each delimited [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0minput places and it can be any combo of text and code cells. So, we can extract all these cells sandwiched between [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose delimited cells and all under a specific activity, all for that activity. You can find an example of a base [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook of the structured kind in the `dev/examples/structured_assignment_example.ipynb` file, if that helps you.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAlso, be mindful of the prompts you create for the agents if there is a maximum token size for them.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mAcknowledge you understand what I am trying to do, present you with suggestions for the instructor mark adjustment [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument kind (with the editable tables and live distribution graph) as well as the final output aggregated marks [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdocument, then list all the artefacts and documents that are produced in this process, and lastly suggest a plan on [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhow to implement this project using Claude Code Web. Also, comment on what you think about this structure I devised [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this project. Let me approve and verify this plan, and then let's start building it ASAP. [39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m> # Agentic Marker System Design[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mI have a project which I want to accomplish ASAP. This task is helping me create a system for draft marking for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignments submitted by students in a class I teach using LLMs invkoed fromCLI. The students submit Jupyter notebook [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles as their submissions. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThere are two kinds of assignments:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m## 1. Fill-in-the-blank style assignments[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThese Jupyter notebook files are filled copies of a fill-in-the-blank kind of notebook, where students start with a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mstarter notebook, and they have to implement what is asked. Some assignments have rubrics, which are included in the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mnotebook, and some don't. Also, the starter notebooks are structured: activities that have to be done by students are [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mspecified by "[A<i>]" in which i is the activity number. The sections students have to fill are enclosed between text [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mcells "*Start student input* â†“" and "*End student input â†‘*". There may be multiple cells between those, and both code [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mand text kinds. They are free to add more cells if they like; however, they are asked not to change anything outside [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthose limits. Also, some cells come with some pieces of code already filled in. I've broken down the task into [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmultiple steps:[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m1. The first step is for a "marking pattern designer" agent to go through the unfilled version of the notebook. The [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0magent identifies the activities that have to be done, how many there are, and their order, and writes a concise but [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdetailed account of what needs to be done for each activity in a separate markdown file. The agent also writes a [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mconcise summary of what students were supposed to have accomplished before, especially as it pertains to the activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mat hand. It also sets up criteria for what successful completion looks like. This all goes into those per-activity [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarkdown files. The goal is for these markdown files to be used by another "marker" agent, so the markdown files [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mshould be written with that in mind. Finally, this agent writes an overall markdown file which includes the rubric, if[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m already included, or creates a sensible rubric if there is none. If creating a sensible rubric requires knowledge [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mabout student proficiency levels and is not inferable from the base notebook itself, the agent may ask the operator, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwho is the instructor of the course, to provide guidance, preferably by asking the agent specific questions about [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhether the agent can assume the students have a specific qualification or not, but if other forms can help better, it[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m is okay. Asking the instructor to describe the proficiency of the students is an available but last resort option. [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mThis questioning, if necessary, is done after the agent has gone through the notebook and written a detailed internal [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mguidance document in markdown for itself (also, at the beginning, the instructor may also optionally provide and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment description package which explain the goals of the assignment, which can also be used, if provided). Then, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mupon clarification, the agent first creates a rubric file if it does not exist and displays it, signalling readiness [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mto move on to the next stage. The instructor can change the rubric until they are happy. Upon confirmation, the agent [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthen creates those per activity marking design documents. Finally, they create that final overall document, which [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mincludes the rubric, given or created, unchanged or updated, extended by the detailed marking criteria and [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mexpectations it created per activity.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m2. Then, if there an n students in the class, and m activities to be done, m sets of n "marker" agents are called, one[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m set per activity. Each agent is provided with the previously created document with the marking pattern design for [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthat activity. These agents are supposed to mark the solutions not with a concrete numerical scheme, but rather [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0midentify all the mistakes the students made, as well as their positive points, and record the result of their marking [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0min a markdown document named after the activity number, as well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched, one per activity, which looks at all the markings done in those markdown [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfiles created by the marker agents, for all students on that activity and based on that, unifies them into a table of [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmistakes and positives and identify the severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also suggest a number for marks to be lost for mistakes, and possible bonus points [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mgiven for positives and write them to another markdown file for that activity the agent was handling.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m4. This is then aggregated in one document for all activities and presented to the instructor in a table, which has [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0malongside it a distribution of marks students will get if the marking scheme is used. The instructor can change the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mmarking number and observe the results on the distribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mExcel file or any form that makes the best sense for this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m which assign the marks based on that scheme and also review the student submission in its entirety to see if there [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mare broader patterns that warrant rare changes for a specific student based on patterns in the overall notebook. These[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m agents, however, do not change anything on their own but rather present their suggestions to the instructor and let [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mhim decide what to do. Also, these agents guess how likely it is for that student to have used an LLM to solve the [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0massignment rather than doing it themselves, as well as any signs that they accomplished something but did not know [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhat they were doing or any other sign related to cheating. They consider these factors when making suggestions to the[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m instructor. Finally at the end, they will produce a concise feedback card for each student listing the marks they got[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m for each activity, what they lost marks on, as well as their total and a brief feedback on what they did.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m6. Finally, an "aggregator" agent runs through all these per-student documents and puts all of that in a CSV format, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mwhich has the student's name, total mark, feedback card, and marks for each activity in that exact order in a format [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mappropriate for that. There may optionally a base CSV file provided by the instructor (for example one coming from [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mMoodle gradebook export) which has student names, in which case, it can be used to create that final document matching[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m the format.[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mtheir positive points, and record the result of their marking in a markdown document named after the activity number, [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mas well as the student's name.[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m3. Then a "normalizer" agent is launched which looks at all the markings done in those markdown files created by the [39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mthe severity of mistakes on a scale from 1 to 10 and the level of positives, again on a scale from 1 to 10.  They also[39m[49m

[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mdistribution of the marks. This interface can be a Google Sheets or Excel file or any form that makes the best sense [39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0mfor this (it needs to have the changeable table and the live updating mark distribution graph).[39m[49m
[48;2;240;240;240m[38;2;0;0;0m5. Upon the instructor finalising and approving the final marking scheme, n "unifier" agents are run, one per student,[39m[49m
